Let $N(k,\ell)$ be the minimal $N$ such that for any $f:\{1,\ldots,N\}\to\{-1,1\}$ there must exist a $k$-term arithmetic progression $P$ such that\[ \left\lvert \sum_{n\in P}f(n)\right\rvert\geq \ell.\]Find good upper bounds for $N(k,\ell)$. Is it true that for any $c>0$ there exists some $C>1$ such that\[N(k,ck)\leq C^k?\]What about\[N(k,2)\leq C^k\]or\[N(k,\sqrt{k})\leq C^k?\]



When $\ell=k$ this is the van der Waerden number $W(k)$ (see [138]). Spencer \cite{Sp73} has proved that if $k=2^tm$ with $m$ odd then\[N(k,1)=2^t(k-1)+1.\]Erd\H{o}s and Graham write that 'no decent bound' is known even for $N(k,2)$.

Erd\H{o}s \cite{Er63d} proved that, for every $c>0$,\[N(k,ck)> (1+\alpha_c)^k\]where $\alpha_c\to 0$ as $c\to 0$ and $\alpha_c\to \sqrt{2}-1$ as $c\to 1$.




References


[Er63d] Erd\H{o}s, P\'al, On combinatorial questions connected with a theorem of
{R}amsey and van der {W}aerden. Mat. Lapok (1963), 29--37.

[Sp73] J. Spencer, Problems 185. Bull. Canad. Math. Soc. (1973), 185.
